titleInfo.title: SPARROW Surface Water-Quality Modeling Nutrients in Watersheds of the Coterminous United States

name.namePart: Smith, R.A., G.E. Schwarz, and R.B. Alexander

Citation_mods.note: Smith, R.A. et al. 1997. SPARROW Surface Water-Quality Modeling Nutrients in Watersheds of the Coterminous United States. Regional interpretation of water-quality monitoring data, Water Resources Research, v. 33, no. 12, pp.2781-2798

titleInfo.title: SPARROW MODELING - Enhancing Understanding of the Nation's Water Quality

name.namePart: Preston, S.D., Alexander, R.B., Woodside, M.D., and Hamilton, P.A.

Citation_mods.note: Preston, S.D., Alexander, R.B., Woodside, M.D., and Hamilton, P.A., 2009, SPARROW MODELING-Enhancing Understanding of the Nation's Water Quality: U.S. Geological Survey Fact Sheet 2009-3019, 6 p.

CommonTerms.Term:
Adjustments
Adjustments allow different management scenarios (changes in model source inputs) to be evaluated with respect to predicted total and incremental flux. Adjustments can be made in one of two ways: by adjusting individual reaches or by adjusting groups of reaches.
To adjust an individual reach's source inputs, first identify the reach on the map. You can identify a reach either by clicking on it with the Identify Reach tool or by searching for it via the Find a reach... button. Once the reach has been identified, navigate to the Model Source Inputs tab, enter the desired input values into the Override column, and click Apply.
To adjust a group of reaches, you must first create an adjustment group of reaches. After identifying a candidate reach on the map, navigate to the Group / Target Membership tab to add it to a group. Once groups are created, right-click the group name on the Adjustments tab and then apply the desired treatments.

Downstream Tracking
Downstream tracking is used to determine the fraction of flux from upstream reaches delivered to a specified downstream outlet reach or water body. To specify a downstream outlet reach, identify the desired reach on the map (using the Identify Reach tool) and then click on the Add Reach as Downstream Outlet button. Alternatively, you may search for downstream outlet reaches either individually or all at once using the Find a reach... button

Term.p: The US is divided into 8 major river basins: New England and Mid-Atlantic; South Atlantic-Gulf and Tennessee; Great Lakes, Ohio, Upper Mississippi and Souris-Red-Rainy; Missouri; Lower Mississippi, Arkansas-White-Red and Texas-Gulf; Rio Grande, Colorado and Great Basin; Pacific Northwest; and California.

The Data Series specifies what data is drawn on the map. The most common model output is the Total Load, which is the average amount of the constituent you would expect to find in a stream, as predicted by the model.
The complete list of data series:

dl.dd: The mean annual load of the constituent (mass per year) leaving each stream reach, as predicted by the model. The load reflects the accumulated mass of the constituent contributed by all sources in the total drainage area upstream of the reach outlet. The load includes the effects of in-stream attenuation processes in all upstream reaches. The mean annual load is a standardized measure of the constituent mass in the stream that reflects the mean quantities of mass that are likely to occur during a specified base year under long-term mean streamflow conditions. Spatial variations in the standardized loads are generally indicative of conditions during higher-flow periods of the year that often occur during the winter and spring. The mean annual conditions described by the model predictions also primarily reflect the effects of natural and human-related processes that supply and remove constituent mass in watersheds over long time periods. The predicted load is also "unadjusted" for measured stream load values at monitoring sites; measured loads are commonly substituted for model predictions ("adjusted" loads) in the calibration procedure to ensure accurate estimation of the model.
An estimate of the prediction error associated with the Total load, based on the model calibration. Units are the same as the units for Total load.

The mean annual load of the constituent (mass per year) entering the stream reach from sources in the incremental drainage area of the reach. The load value reflects the effects of in-stream attenuation processes associated with one half of the reach time of travel (this assumes that the load at approximately the center of reach on average). You can select 'All Sources' or an individual model source to map the incremental load for all of the sources together, or the theoretical load due to a single source.
An estimate of the prediction error associated with the Incremental Load, based on the model calibration. Units are the same as the units for Incremental Load.
The Incremental Load divided by the incremental drainage area of the reach. Units are mass per square kilometer per year.
The average concentration of the constituent in the reach in units of mass per volume. This is calculated by dividing the Total Load by the Streamflow and converting to a standard unit.

The source value is the amount of a particular source added in the reach's drainage area - you must choose a source to map this data series. If you have created adjustments as part of a 'what if' scenario, the adjusted source values are presented.
In many cases the 'source' is not a constituent source. For instance, land area or population could be a source term if it was determined to be a statistically significant surrogate for the constituent.
Also, consider that some source terms may be interdependent. Increasing a hypothetical Agricultural Land Area source value may require decreasing a Developed Land Area source for the set of adjusted reaches.
The mean annual stream flow of the reach, in units of volume per time.

The fraction of the load leaving a reach that arrives at the downstream end of a selected target reach without any removal by natural attenuation processes (e.g., long-term storage; denitrification). You must choose a target reach if you select this series. This definition may not be correct - isn't the attenuation what the DF actually shows?
The incremental load associated with a stream reach that arrives at the downstream end of a selected target reach, in units of mass per year. You must choose a target reach if you select this series.
The total load associated with a stream reach that arrives at the downstream end of a selected target reach, in units of mass per year. You must choose a target reach if you select this series.
The Incremental Delivered Load divided by the drainage area of the reach, in units of mass per square kilometer per year. You must choose a target reach if you select this series.

CommonTerms.Term: Takes into account constituent sources upstream and degradation to describe the annual load of the constituent being transported by national surface waters. Units are typically kilograms/year.
Takes into account only sources of the constituent within the surrounding catchment to show local generation of the constituent independent of the upstream load. Units are typically kilograms/year.

Takes into account only sources of the constituent within the surrounding catchment to show the local generation of the constituent normalized for catchment area. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.
Total load divided by the long-term average flow of the stream reach. Units are typically kilograms/cubic feet.
Displays the location and frequency of constituent sources. Units are typically kilograms/year.
Displays the fraction of incremental load that is delivered to a target reach of interest.
Displays the incremental flux generated by a catchment that is delivered to a target reach of interest. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.
Displays the total flux including sources upstream and within the catchment that is delivered to a target reach of interest. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.
Displays the incremental yield that is delivered to a target reach of interest. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.

Comparison To Original Model
For the selected Data Series, the model prediction based on your adjusted values can be compared to the model prediction based on the original unadjusted values (i.e. the original model prediction).
Two options are available:
Absolute change from original Subtracts the original (unadjusted) model result from the adjusted model result. % change from original Presents the percent increase of the adjusted model result over the original model result. That is:
100 X (adjusted - original) / orginal
Any increase from a original value of zero is considered a 100% change. Any decrease from a original value of zero is considered a -100% change.
The nominal SPARROW DSS model condition is based on source values and streamflow of the model base year.

Binning for Map Color and Legend
Bins determine how values are grouped and displayed on the map. Data are grouped into bins by their values, and data in each bin are displayed with a specific color on the map. By modifying the binning scheme, you can change the way information is presented on your map.
Two auto-generation options are available:
Equal Count Attempt to construct bins such that an equal number of data values fall within each bin. Because the values are sometimes clustered, it is often not possible to generate bins with an even distribution of values into each bin. Equal Range Construct bins such that each bin has an equal numerical interval or range.
If you check Use automatic binning, SPARROW DSS will choose a binning scheme for you based on the map options you have selected. The recommended binning will consist of 5 bins of either equal count or equal range. To specify a custom binning scheme, or to edit colors, uncheck this option and click on the Edit Custom Bins... button.
Controls basic features of how the map is rendered. Click the headings of the subsections for more information on each feature.
Stream segments that extend between confluence with other streams.

Search for Reach Name
Reach names are often reported with abbreviations. You may search for reaches with or without the abbreviations.
Examples:
Search for the South Platte River by entering 'S PLATTE R' or 'PLATTE'
Search for the Little Missouri River, North Fork by entering 'LITTLE MISSOURI R, N FK' or 'MISSOURI'
A watershed that drains to a single stream.

HUC
Hydrologic unit code. The United States is divided and sub-divided into successively smaller hydrologic units which are classified into four levels: regions, sub-regions, accounting units, and cataloging units. The hydrologic units are arranged within each other, from the smallest (cataloging units) to the largest (regions). Each hydrologic unit is identified by a unique hydrologic unit code (HUC) consisting of two to eight digits based on the four levels of classification in the hydrologic unit system. The first level of classification (HUC2) divides the Nation into 21 major geographic areas that contain either the drainage area of a major river, such as the Missouri region, or the combined drainage areas of a series of rivers, such as the Texas-Gulf region, which includes a number of rivers draining into the Gulf of Mexico. The second level of classification (HUC4) divides the 21 regions into 221 subregions that include the area drained by a river system, a reach of a river and its tributaries in that reach, a closed basin(s), or a group of streams forming a coastal drainage area. The third level of classification (HUC6) subdivides many of the subregions into 378 accounting units that are nested within, or can be equivalent to the subregions. The fourth level of classification (HUC8) includes 2,264 cataloging units, which are geographic areas representing part of all of a surface drainage basin, a combination of drainage basins, or a distinct hydrologic feature. These units subdivide the subregions and accounting units into smaller areas.
Calculates the average, maximum, minimum, or sum of the model output when the map displays over HUC.

Display Reaches or Catchments
Selecting Reaches will draw individual reach lines (water bodies) on the map. Selecting Catchments will draw each catchment region (land area surrounding each reach). In both cases, the color used to render the reach or catchment is based on the binning scheme selected on the Map Controls tab.

Watershed Area
The area of land that drains all the upstream streams and rainfall to the stream reach. The word watershed is sometimes used interchangeably with drainage basin or catchment.

EDA Name
NOAA name identifying estuarine/coastal drainage areas for major estuaries in the United States.

EDA Code
NOAA code identifying estuarine/coastal drainage areas for major estuaries in the United States.

Data Series Help: The Data Series specifies what data is drawn on the map. The most common model output is the Total Load, which is the average amount of the constituent you would expect to find in a stream, as predicted by the model. The complete list of data series: Total Load The mean annual load of the constituent (mass per year) leaving each stream reach, as predicted by the model. The load reflects the accumulated mass of the constituent contributed by all sources in the total drainage area upstream of the reach outlet. The load includes the effects of in-stream attenuation processes in all upstream reaches. The mean annual load is a standardized measure of the constituent mass in the stream that reflects the mean quantities of mass that are likely to occur during a specified base year under long-term mean streamflow conditions. Spatial variations in the standardized loads are generally indicative of conditions during higher-flow periods of the year that often occur during the winter and spring. The mean annual conditions described by the model predictions also primarily reflect the effects of natural and human-related processes that supply and remove constituent mass in watersheds over long time periods. The predicted load is also "unadjusted" for measured stream load values at monitoring sites; measured loads are commonly substituted for model predictions ("adjusted" loads) in the calibration procedure to ensure accurate estimation of the model.
Standard Error of Total Load An estimate of the prediction error associated with the Total load, based on the model calibration. Units are the same as the units for Total load.
Incremental Load The mean annual load of the constituent (mass per year) entering the stream reach from sources in the incremental drainage area of the reach. The load value reflects the effects of in-stream attenuation processes associated with one half of the reach time of travel (this assumes that the load at approximately the center of reach on average). You can select 'All Sources' or an individual model source to map the incremental load for all of the sources together, or the theoretical load due to a single source.
Standard Error of Incremental Load An estimate of the prediction error associated with the Incremental Load, based on the model calibration. Units are the same as the units for Incremental Load.
Incremental Yield The Incremental Load divided by the incremental drainage area of the reach. Units are mass per square kilometer per year.
Concentration The average concentration of the constituent in the reach in units of mass per volume. This is calculated by dividing the Total Load by the Streamflow and converting to a standard unit.
Source Value The source value is the amount of a particular source added in the reach's drainage area - you must choose a source to map this data series. If you have created adjustments as part of a 'what if' scenario, the adjusted source values are presented.
In many cases the 'source' is not a constituent source. For instance, land area or population could be a source term if it was determined to be a statistically significant surrogate for the constituent.
Also, consider that some source terms may be interdependent. Increasing a hypothetical Agricultural Land Area source value may require decreasing a Developed Land Area source for the set of adjusted reaches.
Streamflow The mean annual stream flow of the reach, in units of volume per time.
Delivery Fraction The fraction of the load leaving a reach that arrives at the downstream end of a selected target reach without any removal by natural attenuation processes (e.g., long-term storage; denitrification). You must choose a target reach if you select this series.
Incremental Delivered Load The incremental load associated with a stream reach that arrives at the downstream end of a selected target reach, in units of mass per year. You must choose a target reach if you select this series.
Total Delivered Load The total load associated with a stream reach that arrives at the downstream end of a selected target reach, in units of mass per year. You must choose a target reach if you select this series.
Incremental Delivered Yield The Incremental Delivered Load divided by the drainage area of the reach, in units of mass per square kilometer per year. You must choose a target reach if you select this series.
Comparison to Original Model Help:
For the selected Data Series, the model prediction based on your adjusted values can be compared to the model prediction based on the original unadjusted values (i.e. the original model prediction).
Two options are available: Absolute change from original Subtracts the original (unadjusted) model result from the adjusted model result. % change from original Presents the percent increase of the adjusted model result over the original model result. That is:
100 X (adjusted - original) / original
Any increase from a original value of zero is considered a 100% change. Any decrease from an original value of zero is considered a -100% change.
For more information on the SPARROW model, go to http://water.usgs.gov/nawqa/sparrow/.
